doubt.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a feeling of being not sure whether something is true or right
doubt.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: There was still one little nagging doubt at the back of his mind.
There’s no doubt that he was a major artist.
The incident raises doubts about the safety of nuclear power.
Some government ministers had serious doubts as to whether the policy would work.
doubt.translation[0].note_box[0].section: have doubts
Scientists still have some doubts about the theory.
have your doubts
Everyone else thinks it’s a good idea, but I have my doubts.
have no/little doubt
I have no doubt that you are right.
be in no/any doubt about something
The government is in no doubt about the seriousness of the situation.
leave no/little doubt (that)
The evidence left no doubt that he was the murderer.
cast/throw doubt on something
Research has cast doubt on the safety of mobile phones.
raise doubts about something
His handling of the matter has raised doubts about his competence.
call/throw something into doubt
The accuracy of his account was called into doubt.
express/voice doubts
Many people expressed doubts about the necessity of the war.
serious/grave doubts
They have some serious doubts as to his honesty.
considerable doubts
I had considerable doubts about accepting the job.
a lingering/nagging doubt
I still had a nagging doubt that there might be something seriously wrong.
there is no/little/some doubt
There is little doubt that he will play for England one day.
without a shadow of a doubt
I knew without a shadow of a doubt that I was going to win.
an element of doubt
There’s an element of doubt about his true age as he doesn’t have a birth certificate.
not the slightest doubt
There’s not the slightest doubt in my mind about it.
doubt.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to think that something may not be true or that it is unlikely
doubt.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: ‘Do you think there’ll be any tickets left?’ ‘I doubt it (=I don’t think so).’
I doubt we’ll ever see him again.
You can complain, but I doubt if it’ll make any difference.
doubt.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to not trust or have confidence in someone
doubt.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: I never doubted myself. I always knew I could play tennis at this level.
She loved him, and had never doubted him.
I have no reason to doubt his word (=think that he is lying).
doubt.translation[1].note_box[0].items[0: You doubt whether someone can do something
I doubt whether we can afford a new car
She doubted whether she could trust him again
doubt.translation[1].note_box[0].items[1: You doubt whether something will happen
I doubt whether the plan will work
He doubted whether this would happen
doubt.translation[1].note_box[0].items[2: doubt if with the same meaning as doubt whether
I doubt if we can afford a new car
I doubt if the plan will work
doubt.translation[1].note_box[0].items[3: I doubt that we can afford a new car
I doubt that the plan will work
doubt.translation[1].note_box[0].items[4: The verb doubt is not usually used in the progressive You say
I doubt he’ll come to the party
I am doubting he’ll come to the party
doubt.translation[1].note_box[1].section: doubt
to think that something may not be true or that it is unlikely
‘Do you think she really is eighteen?’ ‘I doubt it.’
There was so much noise that I doubt if anyone slept.
be doubtful/dubious
to doubt that something will happen, is true, or is a good idea
Economists are doubtful that the situation will improve this year.
‘You can eat the whole fish including the head.’ Janey looked dubious.
When my husband suggested emigrating, I was dubious at first.
Mum looked doubtful when I suggested having a party for all my friends.
have reservations
to feel that a plan or idea may not be good because you think there may be some problems with it
Health care professionals had reservations about giving both vaccines together.
have misgivings
to feel worried about doing something, because it may have a bad result
Ralph had serious misgivings about changing his career at the age of 50.
have mixed feelings
to be unsure exactly how you feel about something or someone because there are both good and bad things about them
I have very mixed feelings about moving house – it’s exciting but I’ll miss this area.
have second thoughts
to start having doubts about whether a decision you have just made is the right one
I liked the dress in the shop, but when I got it home I had second thoughts.
